Oh no :( 
 I'm sorry to hear that 
 I've also struggled with loneliness, it must feel unpleasant :( 
 Did you know that being alone and loneliness aren't the same thing? 
 You can achieve contentment and happiness without the presence of others 
 I started to enjoy and cherish my time alone by starting to plan my day and participated in various activities. 
 The activities weren't all fancy or anything, some were simple, like having lunch outside! 
 Why don't you try? List out some activities you're interested in or meant to do but haven't done.

patterns: How do I improve my self esteem?
How do I raise my low self esteem?
responses:
You can start by identifying negative beliefs and thoughts you have about yourself, such as, "No one cares about me" and noting them down. 
 Next, write down things that challenges those beliefs, such as, "My mom calls to chat every week". 
 You can also write down positive things other people say about you! 
 Put this list somewhere you can see, like beside your mirror or on your fridge, so you can remind yourself of how cool you are B)

You can give yourself a mini pep talk to boost your confidence 
 Phrases like "I got this!" 
 "I can do it!" 
 or "If I did it once, I can do it again!"

I'm sorry you're going through this :( 
 When someone is feeling down or anxious, they often lose motivation to do activities, even ones they usually enjoy. 
 People who are managing low and anxious moods find it hard to feel happiness or pleasure, even while doing things they usually enjoy. 
 However, the best thing to do is to start some sort of gratifying activity, even without motivation to begin with. 
 It may be hard to start if you don't think you'll enjoy it, but data shows that just by doing the activity can help improve your mood over time and can also keep a good mood going. 
 For me, when I listen to music, my mood instantly lifts up and it keeps me going throughout the day! 
 Avoiding fun activities when feeling low can actually increase those negative feelings over time, so we want to avoid that. 
 Why don't you start listing down some fun activities to try out this week? Here are some examples: 
 Reading 
 Listening to music 
 Singing 
 Cleaning 
 Walking 
 Cooking or Baking

It must be frustrating to not be able to fall asleep even if you want to :( 
 Many people tend to do a lot of thinking at night, even when they don't want to and would rather get some rest. 
 Dr Rachel Manber, an expert in sleep and professir at Stanford recommends a few tips to help you: 
 1. Purposefully set aside around 20-30 minutes of designated 'worry time' ideally at least 2 hours before bed time. During those 20-30 minutes, you can write down whatever's worrying you and then solutions to address those concerns. 
 So that at night, whenever you're tempted to let your mind race, simple remind yourself that you've already addressed those concerns and need to let it go, or tell yourself that you'll worry about it during your set time tomorrow instead. 
 2. Make a to-do list for tomorrow 
 This way, you wont stay up thinking of everything that needs to be done the following day. 
 The to-do list should contain manageable items, like buying groceries, or completing homework. 
 3. Create a buffer zone that takes up about 30 minutes between the hustle and bustle of the day and the tranquility of sleep. 
 You can use this time to unwind from the day and prepare your body for sleep. 
 You can do anything that brings you calm and peace, such as taking a hot bath or shower, reading a book or listening to calming music. 
 If possible, pick an offline, no screens activity as bright devices or lights in your home can keep you alert at bed time. 
 Hopefully this helped you fall asleep better! Good night and sweet dreams! :)
